Impact of diverse active sites on MoS2 catalyst: Competition on active site formation and selectivity of thiophene hydrodesulfurization reaction Chen Guo a b Tian Zhang a Mang Niu a ⁎ Shoufu Cao a Shuxian Wei a Zhaojie Wang a Wenyue Guo a Xiaoqing Lu a ⁎ Chi-Man Lawrence Wu b a School of Materials Science and Engineering, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao, Shandong 266580, PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering China University of Petroleum Qingdao Shandong 266580 PR China b Department of Materials Science and Engineering, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Department of Materials Science and Engineering City University of Hong Kong Hong Kong Special Administrative Region ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract MoS2 is an efficient catalyst widely used in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction. Coordinatively unsaturated active sites (CUS) on defective MoS2 clusters are the most active positions for HDS reaction. In this study, we investigated CUS formation competition and thiophene HDS reaction mechanism at diverse active sites on MoS2 nanoclusters by using density functional theory. First, we constructed five defective MoS2 clusters with different CUSs. The calculated formation energies and Gibbs free energies of these CUSs indicated that the MoS2 clusters with single-corner or -edge CUSs were the favorable structures under HDS condition, especially the former type. Subsequently, thiophene adsorption configurations and HDS reactions at the corner and edge CUSs on MoS2 clusters were elucidated. Results showed that the corner CUS was more beneficial for thiophene adsorption than the edge CUS due to the smaller steric hindrance effect. For HDS process at the corner CUS, reaction via hydrogenation route was more competitive, and the reaction formed 2-butene as a product and tetrahydrothiophene as an impurity. By contrast, at the edge CUS, the direct desulfurization route with butadiene production was more energetically favorable, indicating an enhanced catalytic HDS property. This work provides theoretical basis in screening catalyst active sites and catalytic reaction products in industrial HDS processes. Keywords MoS2 cluster Coordinatively unsaturated active site Hydrodesulfurization mechanism Density functional theory 1 Introduction Sulfur pollutants emitted from burning fossil fuels severely contaminate the environment, and this status quo has aroused the attention of all sectors of the society. To address the environmental problems caused by sulfur pollutants, application of ultra-low sulfur diesel technology in petroleum industry has become imperative and initiated legislation globally [1–3]. Deep hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of refractory sulfur compounds is one of the most effective methods in desulfurizing industrial crude oil [4–7]. Given the high activity, MoS2 catalysts have been widely used in hydrotreatment of sulfur-containing oil fractions via the HDS process [8,9]. Coordinatively unsaturated active sites (CUSs) on MoS2 have been reported as important sites both for sulfur compound adsorptions and hydrogenation reactions [10,11]. CUS formation can be described by the following equation [12–14]: (1) V–S + H2 → V + H2S where V is the CUS. The corner and edge sites on triangular or hexagonal MoS2 nanoclusters present considerably different chemical characteristics, as demonstrated by numerous experimental and theoretical studies [8,15–18]. For instance, Tuxen et al. [8] observed that the Mo-edge of MoS2 cluster which pre-exposed to atomic H favored S vacancy formation at the edge site under ultrahigh vacuum (UHV). By contrast, corner S vacancy formation tended to take place on S-edge under the same condition. Tuxen et al. [17] found that dibenzothiophenes (DBT) were physisorbed at the corner sites of Mo-edge terminated cluster, whereas chemisorption of DBT on S-edge corner vacancies is favorable under UHV. However, due to the steric hindrance, edge vacancies on Mo-edge adversely affected DBT adsorption. As for Co-promoted MoS2 particles, Šarić et al. [18] reported that vacancies tended to exist at the corner sites of hexagonal CoMoS particle. Both corner vacancies and Co-promoted S-edge displayed higher activity toward complex sulfide molecules than Mo-edge in the hydrogenation pathway under HDS condition. Previous theoretical researches related to MoS2 HDS catalyst mainly focused on vacancy formation mechanism [19,20], sulfur-compound adsorption situation [21,22], and hydrogenation reaction process [20,23]. However, the roles of diverse active sites during HDS were not clear yet. In this work, new insight on the evaluation of various properties among diverse CUSs, including formation competition, electronic structure property, and selectivity of reaction routes and products at each CUS would be elucidated. Being a typical aromatic sulfur compound, thiophene and its derivatives have been used to study HDS reactions. During HDS process, these molecules take two parallel routes: the direct desulfurization route (DDS) and the hydrogenation route (HYD) [24–27]. The competition between the two routes is mainly determined by the types of organic sulfur compounds and the catalytic active sites [26,28]. Herein, we selected thiophene on the basis of its simple structure to systematically illustrate its HDS mechanisms at different CUSs on MoS2 clusters. In this study, density functional theory (DFT) was employed to investigate the HDS reactions at different CUSs on MoS2 clusters. Given that Mo-edge with 50% sulfur coverage is the most stable structure under HDS condition [10,29,30], five different CUSs were constructed on the 50% S-coverage Mo-edge. To illustrate the competition among these CUSs on MoS2 clusters, we systematically investigated their geometric structures, formation energies, free energies, and electronic structure characteristics. The thiophene adsorption configurations and HDS reaction mechanisms at the corner and edge CUSs were subsequently calculated. Both DDS and HYD routes were taken into account. This work is expected to shed light on the different effects of diverse CUSs on MoS2 clusters during HDS process. Moreover, by investigating CUS formation and HDS reaction mechanisms on defective MoS2 clusters, this study will provide a feasible method to regulate active sites and HDS products. 2 Theoretical methods All calculations were performed by using spin unrestricted DFT with the program package DMol3 in Materials Studio of Accelrys Inc [31–33], using GGA-PW91 exchange-correlation functional [34–36]. To take the relativistic effect into account, the density functional semicore pseudopotential (DSPP) method [37] was used for Mo atoms, whereas the S, C, and H atoms were treated with an all-electron basis set. The valence electron functions were expanded into a set of numerical atomic orbitals by double numerical plus polarization functions. The self-consistent field (SCF) density convergence tolerance was 1 × 10−5 ha. A Fermi smearing of 0.005 ha and a real-space cutoff of 4.5 Å were applied to improve the computational performance. To investigate the properties of various active sites on MoS2 catalysts, a 50% S-coverage non-periodic triangular MoS2 cluster was constructed as previously described [17,38–41]. Based on the triangular MoS2 cluster, we constructed five defective structures with different CUSs in Fig. 1 . The adsorption energies of thiophene on Mo-edge was calculated as follows: (2) E ads = E gas/clu − E clu − E gas The transition state (TS) searches were performed at the same theoretical level with the complete Linear Synchronous Transit/Quadratic Synchronous Transit (LST/QST) method [42–44] and the Root Mean Square (RMS) force was below 0.003 Ha/Å. The reaction energy ΔE and barrier energy E a reported herein were calculated as follows: (3) ΔE = E FS − E IS (4) E a = E TS − E IS where E IS, E TS, and E FS represent the total energy of initial state (IS), transition state (TS), and final state (FS), respectively. Correlative thermodynamic calculations were performed and the Gibbs free energy variation for the CUS formation process can be approximately calculated by the following Equation [12,13,18,45,46]: (5) Δ G T , P = Δ E 0 + Δ H ( T ) - T Δ S ( T ) + R T ln P ( H 2 S ) P ( H 2 ) where ΔE 0 is the electronic energy difference of the reaction, R is the ideal gas constant, P is the pressure of each gas component, and ΔE 0 + ΔH(T) is the reaction enthalpy. Enthalpy and entropy can be obtained by the following expression [47]: (6) H(T) = E 0 + ZVPE + E vib(T) + E trans(T) + E rot(T) (7) S(T) = S vib(T) + S trans(T) + S rot(T) where the indices of vib, trans, and rot account for the vibrational, translational, and rotational contributions, respectively. ZVPE is the zero point vibrational energy. For atoms of the MoS2 cluster, only vibrational contributions to enthalpy and entropy were considered, while translational and rotational components were ignored [23,47,48]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CUS formations at different sites The optimized geometry of MoS2 cluster is shown in Fig. 1a. The outermost Mo atoms move slightly after optimization. The long and the short Mo–Mo distances change to 3.50 Å and 2.81 Å relative to the initial distance of 3.17 Å, respectively, in good agreement with previous findings [21,22]. Heterogeneous Mo–Mo intervals result in the characteristic Mo–S bonds. The Mo1–S1 (Mo4–S3) bond length is 2.30 Å. The bond lengths of Mo2–S1 (Mo3–S3) and Mo2–S2 (Mo3–S2) are 2.47 Å and 2.44 Å, respectively. The CUSs are built by removing the terminal S atoms from the equilibrium Mo-edge. Five defective MoS2 structures, labeled as V1-V5, are shown in Fig. 1b–f. The vacancy formation energy of CUS is calculated as follows [25,30]: (8) Δ E vac = E * + E H 2 S ( g ) − E H 2 ( g ) − E S − * The optimized defective MoS2 clusters with single CUSs at the corner and edge sites are shown in Fig. 1b–c, respectively. After the formation of corner CUS (labeled as V1), the distance between Mo1 and Mo2 is elongated from 2.81 Å to 3.40 Å without the constraint of the terminal S1 atom. Moreover, the originally long Mo2–Mo3 distance sharply decreases to 3.00 Å and the Mo2–S2 bond length shortens from 2.44 Å to 2.23 Å, indicating a more stable Mo–S bond strength. The vacancy formation energy of V1 is 1.07 eV. For the edge CUS (labeled as V2; Fig. 1c), the Mo2–Mo3 distance extends to 3.59 Å. Meanwhile, the corner short Mo1–Mo2 distance and Mo2–S1 bond shorten slightly. The vacancy formation energy of V2 is 1.18 eV, consistent with experimental results [49], which is 0.11 eV higher than that of V1. As previously reported, the “short” vacancy formation (removing terminal S atoms from short-distance Mo–Mo) is more endothermic than the “long” vacancy formation (removing terminal S atoms from long-distance Mo–Mo) [21]. However, in our MoS2 cluster models, the formation of corner “short” vacancy (V1) is even less endothermic than the formation of the edge “long” vacancy (V2). This further illustrates that the formation of corner CUS is energetically favorable on the 50% S-coverage Mo-edge of the MoS2 cluster. Defective MoS2 clusters with two CUSs (labeled as V3 and V4) are both constructed based on the V1 configuration. For the V3 structure (Fig. 1d), the terminal S atom at the other corner is removed. The Mo3–Mo4 distance is 3.43 Å, and the Mo2–Mo3 distance is decreased from 3.00 Å to 2.81 Å. The vacancy formation energy of V3 is 1.19 eV, slightly larger than the formation energies of V1 and V2 structures. For the V4 structure (Fig. 1e), the vacancy formation energy is 1.50 eV, which is larger than that of V3. As mentioned above, the presence of V1 leads to a shorter Mo2–Mo3 distance, causing the larger vacancy formation energy of V4. After the V4 formation, the Mo3–Mo4 distance is shortened from 2.93 Å to 2.80 Å. Fig. 1f shows the defective MoS2 cluster (labeled as V5) constructed by the removal of the S atom from V3. In V5, the Mo-edge is not covered with S atom, and the vacancy formation energy reaches up to 3.34 eV. The Mo–Mo distances range from 3.15 Å to 3.19 Å. These results show that once a S atom is removed and results in CUS formation, the interactions of adjacent Mo–S bonds are partly enhanced, and the adjacent S terminated site would turn into a “short” Mo–Mo bond; thus, the formation of single CUSs on the 50% S-coverage Mo-edge of MoS2 cluster is competitive. Reaction conditions are widely believed to remarkably influence CUS formation on MoS2 catalysts [18,23,46]. As shown in Eq. (5), temperature and partial pressure of H2 (H2S) are the major factors affecting the free energies of CUS formations. ΔGT , P obviously decreases with the increase in P(H2); thus, an elevated partial pressure of H2 is favorable for CUS formation. To investigate the relationship between free energy and temperature, we performed the related calculations as follows. The HDS conditions are set as 573 K, 38 atm of H2, and 0.13 atm of H2S [18,24]. Under the HDS condition, the calculated Gibbs formation free energy variation of V1–V5 are 0.25 eV, 0.38 eV, 0.53 eV, 0.71 eV, and 2.57 eV, respectively, consistent with previous results [18]. Fig. 2 shows the free energies of V1–V5 at different temperatures (under HDS pressure condition, P(H2) = 38 atm and P(H2S) = 0.13 atm). ΔGT , P and T show an approximately linear correlation, that is, ΔGT , P gradually decreases as T increases. The result is consistent with the experimental result that HDS conversion increases as temperature goes up on MoS2 catalyst [50]. When the temperature reaches 700 K, V1 is likely to form spontaneously, and the temperature for spontaneous generation of V2 is nearly 750 K. By contrast, the spontaneous vacancy formation reactions of V4 and V5 could only take place at quite high temperatures. Single CUSs, including the corner and edge CUSs, are competitive structures under HDS condition. Therefore, we calculated the adsorption configurations and HDS processes of thiophene at these two sites as presented in the following sections. 3.2 Thiophene adsorption at the corner and edge CUSs The stable adsorption configurations of thiophene at the corner and edge CUSs are shown in Fig. 3 a–f (labeled as C-1 to C-6) and Fig. 3g–i (labeled as E-1 to E-3), respectively. Table 1 lists the adsorption energies, structural parameters, and net charges of these adsorption configurations. The most stable adsorption configuration at the corner CUS is C-4 (E ads = −1.20 eV), in which thiophene is “flatly” adsorbed on Mo1. In C-4, π-systems of thiophene interact with Mo1 via the η5-type bonding, and the intramolecular C2, C5, and S atoms are bound to Mo1. Among all the adsorption configurations, the Mo1–Cα bond lengths (2.26 Å and 2.27 Å) in C-4 are the shortest, which are possibly the main reason of the largest adsorption energy. E-1 (Fig. 3g) is the most stable configuration at the edge CUS, and the adsorption energy of thiophene is −0.52 eV. In E-1 configuration, thiophene is “vertically” adsorbed at the bridge site via the σ-type bonding of S atom, wherein the Mo-type bonding of S atom, wherein the MS bond lengths are 2.60 Å and 2.61 Å. After adsorption, the Cα–S bond lengths are slightly elongated to 1.76 Å from 1.73 Å, illustrating the initial activation of the Cα–S bond. Frontier molecular orbital theory and electrostatic potential are effective tools to illustrate the properties of the catalytic active sites and the adsorption conditions [48,51]; thus, the properties of the corner and edge CUSs are calculated by using these tools. Given that electrons transfer from thiophene to the MoS2 cluster (Table 1), the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the CUS plays a significant role during the adsorption process [51]. The LUMOs of the perfect MoS2 cluster, V1, and V2 are displayed in Fig. 4 a–c. In Fig. 4b, no unoccupied orbitals are found on Mo2; thus, the interaction between thiophene and Mo1 is dominant at the corner CUS. As for the edge CUS (Fig. 4c), the “vertical” adsorption of thiophene at bridge site is available because of the unoccupied orbital contributions of both Mo2 and Mo3. By contrast, due to the lack of unoccupied orbitals on Mo2 (Fig. 4b), no bridge adsorption configuration of thiophene is observed at the corner CUS. Fig. 4d–f show the electrostatic potentials V(r) mapped on the cap of the ρ(r) = 0.001 contour. This mapping is used to identify the host sites to which nucleophiles (red zone) and electrophiles (blue zone) should bind [52–54]. The V(r) map of the perfect MoS2 cluster is displayed in Fig. 4d. After the removal of S atom from the MoS2 cluster at the corner and edge sites, the Lewis acid sites are exposed (Fig. 4e–f). Lewis acidity at the corner CUS is relatively strong, indicating a high electrophilic ability and a strong interaction with thiophene. However, the nucleophilic ability of terminal S atoms at the corner and edge CUSs is weakened compared with that on the 50% S-coverage Mo-edge. 3.3 HDS reactions at the corner CUS Previous experimental and theoretical researches pointed out that [25,26,55,56], during thiophene HDS processes, the selectivity of reaction routes and products depend on hydrogenation orders and reaction loci. Fig. 5 shows the potential energy surface for the HDS reactions of thiophene at the corner CUS, that is, HYD and DDS route. Table 2 shows their elementary reactions together with the energy barriers and reaction energies. The relative structures of IS, TS, and FS are shown in Figs. 6 and S1. A previous study has shown that the heterolytic dissociation process of H2 on 50% S-coverage Mo-edge forms both S–H and Mo–H species [57], indicating that there are two co-adsorption sites (Mo and S) for atomic H during the HDS reaction. Herein, all possible co-adsorption structures as IS are taken into account. Considering the symmetric adsorption configuration of thiophene, only one route (IS1 → IM1) is analyzed in the first hydrogenation to C2 or C5. The same approach is applied in the subsequent hydrogenation reactions that begin with symmetric adsorbate. Thus, for the first hydrogenation step, three possible reaction routes are obtained. Notably, as H transfers to C2, two intermediates of IM1 (Fig. 6) and IM2 (Fig. S1) are observed due to the different transfer directions. 2-hydrothiophene (IM1) is one of the intermediates of the initial hydrogenation in the HYD pathway, whereas IM2 is the initial intermediate in the DDS pathway. In Reaction 1 (IS1 → IM1; Fig. 6), the C2 atom does not bind to Mo1 after hydrogenation. Instead, a new Mo–C3 bond forms. This step is exothermic by 0.67 eV with an extremely small energy barrier of 0.07 eV, indicating a quite competitive elementary reaction. In Reaction 2 (IS2 → IM2; Fig. S1), the C2–S bond with a distance of 3.09 Å is completely broken. After the C2–S bond scission, the S atom binds to Mo2. As the first step along the DDS pathway, Reaction 2 is exothermic by 1.02 eV with an energy barrier of 1.11 eV. Notably in IM2, the C2 still binds to Mo1, indicating that desorption of subsequent hydrogenation products could not happen unless another H interacts with C2; thus, the DDS route is unfavorable starting with the V1 site. In Reaction 3 (IS3 → IM3; Fig. S1), the H migrates from S to C3, forming 3-hydrothiophene. The energy barrier is 1.72 eV and the reaction energy is 0.19 eV. Compared with the other two initial hydrogenation steps, Reaction 1 is considerably more competitive due to its lowest energy barrier. Therefore, the intermediate of 2-hydrothiophene is selected as the IS for the subsequent hydrogenation reactions. For the subsequent hydrogenation steps, three possible elementary reactions are analyzed. In Reaction 4 (IS4 → IM4; Fig. 6), the adatom H migrates from Mo1 to C5, forming 2,5-dihydrothiophene. In IM4, 2,5-dihydrothiophene is adsorbed at the corner CUS with the formation of Mo1–C3 and Mo1–C4 bonds. The calculated energy barrier and reaction energy in Reaction 4 are 0.45 eV and -1.63 eV, respectively. In Reaction 5 (IS5 → IM5; Fig. S1), the H transfers from S to C4. 2,4-dihydrothiophene is adsorbed at the corner CUS with Mo1–C3 and Mo1–C5 bonds. This hydrogenation step is endothermic by 0.59 eV, and the energy barrier is 0.93 eV. When the adatom H transfers from S to C3 in Reaction 6 (IS6 → IM6; Fig. S1), 2,3-dihydrothiophene forms. This elementary reaction is endothermic by 0.19 eV. The long H transfer pathway IS6 → IM6 leads to a high energy barrier of 1.24 eV. After the second hydrogenation steps, three reaction pathways (IM4 → IM7 → IM11, IM4 → IM8 → FS1, and IM5 → IM9 → IM12) are obtained. In Reaction 7 (IS7 → IM7; Fig. 6), the H transfers from S to C3. The adsorbate in IM7 is adsorbed at the CUS with Mo1–C4 and Mo2–S bonds. The energy barrier of this step is 1.05 eV, and the reaction energy is 0.13 eV. Then in Reaction 11 (IS11 → IM11; Fig. 6), the H binds to C4, forming tetrahydrothiophene. In IM11, tetrahydrothiophene is adsorbed at the corner CUS with the Mo2–S bond of 2.61 Å. This step is endothermic by 0.68 eV with an energy barrier of 1.30 eV. No other routes are available for further hydrogenation reactions of tetrahydrothiophene. By contrast, the desorption of tetrahydrothiophene is endothermic by 0.58 eV with an energy barrier of 0.62 eV. The result shows that this pathway is unfavorable for the deep HDS. Pathway IM5 → IM9 → IM12 is similar to the above pathway IM4 → IM7 → IM11. Tetrahydrothiophene is produced as an impurity. The energy barrier and reaction energy in Reaction 9 (IS9 → IM9) are 1.40 eV and −0.83 eV, respectively. Those in Reaction 12 (IS12 → IM12) are 1.21 eV and 0.37 eV. The higher rate-limiting step barrier energy (1.40 eV vs 1.30 eV) indicates that this pathway is slightly unfavorable. As for the route IM4 → IM8 → FS1, the H migrates from Mo2 to C2 in Reaction 8 (IS8 → IM8; Fig. 6). In IM8, the C2–S bond completely breaks, and S atom of thiophene is located at the bridge site between Mo1 and Mo2. The energy barrier and reaction energy of Reaction 8 are 1.88 eV and −1.39 eV, respectively. Then in Reaction 10 (IM10 → FS1), C5 binds to the H and the C5–S bond breaks, indicating the HYD route is completed with the formation of 2-butene. This step is exothermic by 0.76 eV and the energy barrier is 1.08 eV. Therefore, the favorable HYD route at the corner CUS can be summarized as IS → IM1 → IM4 → IM8 → FS1. 3.4 HDS reactions at the edge CUS The elementary HDS reactions of thiophene at the edge CUS are listed in Table 3 . Fig. 7 shows the potential energy surface, and the relevant structures are shown in Figs. 8 and S2. Similar to the reactions at the corner CUS, three different initial hydrogenation steps are obtained at the edge CUS. In Reaction 1 (IS1 → IM1; Fig. 8), the H transfers from Mo3 to C2. In IM1, the C2–S bond with a distance of 3.32 Å completely breaks; thus, Reaction 1 represents the initial step of the DDS pathway. This step is exothermic by 1.01 eV with an energy barrier of 0.75 eV. Given the different transfer directions of the adatom H, another intermediate 2-hydrothiophene forms when the first H transfers from Mo3 to C2 (Reaction 2, IS2 → IM2; Fig. 8). The energy barrier and reaction energy of this step are 0.75 eV and 0.18 eV, respectively. In Reaction 3 (IS3 → IM3; Fig. S2), the H transfers from S3 to C3, forming 3-hydrothiophene. The energy barrier reaches up to 1.72 eV and the reaction energy is 0.19 eV. Reaction 2 is competitive with Reaction 3 along the initial HYD reaction. Given its good kinetic and thermodynamic properties, Reaction 2 is favorable, and thus the subsequent HYD reactions should proceed based on the intermediate 2-hydrothiophene. The second steps of hydrogenation reactions are denoted as Reactions 4–6. In Reaction 4 (IS4 → FS1; Fig. 8), the H approaches to C5 from Mo3, forming butadiene. The C5–S bond length is elongated from 1.78 Å to 1.92 Å, indicating that the C5–S bond is significantly weakened. This step is exothermic by 0.58 eV, and the energy barrier is 0.79 eV. Then the butadiene could detach from the surface at a desorption energy of 0.16 eV, indicating the completion of the desulfurization process. To sum up, the entire DDS pathway at the edge CUS is presented as IS1 → IM1 → FS1. For the hydrogenation reactions of 2-hydrothiophene, two possible routes of Reactions 5 and 6 are found. In Reaction 5 (IS5 → IM5, Fig. 8), the H transfers from Mo3 to C2 and the C2 S bond is broken. Due to the interaction between S3 and the coordinatively unsaturated C3 atom, the adsorbate in IM5 is tilted. This step is exothermic by 1.15 eV with an energy barrier of 0.18 eV. In Reaction 6 (IS6 → IM6; Fig. S2), the adatom H transfers from Mo3 to C5, forming 2,5-dihydrothiophene. The calculated energy barrier and reaction energy of Reaction 6 are 0.45 eV and −0.63 eV, respectively. In short, Reactions 5 and 6, as the second hydrogenation steps of the HYD pathway, are both competitively through kinetic and thermodynamic analyses. Thereby, the subsequent hydrogenation reactions starting with IM5 and IM6 are considered. In Reaction 7 (IS7 → IM7; Fig. 8), the adatom H migrates from S3 to C3; the short H removal distance renders a low energy barrier of 0.17 eV, and the reaction energy is -1.01 eV. In the following Reaction 14 (IS14 → FS5; Fig. S2), the C5 atom combines with the H from S3–H species and forms 1-butene, indicating the completion of the HYD pathway. This step is exothermic by 0.70 eV with a high energy barrier of 1.55 eV. Another route to form 1-butene is IM6 → IM9 → FS4. In the former step (Reaction 9, IS9 → IM9; Fig. S2), the H approaches to C3. Notably, after hydrogenation, the C5–S bond is broken. The energy barrier and reaction energy in Reaction 9 are 0.91 eV and −1.37 eV, respectively. 1-butene is subsequently formed after H transferred from Mo3 to C2 (Reaction 13, IS13 → FS4; Fig. S2). The energy barrier in Reaction 13 is 1.57 eV, which is higher than that in Reaction 9, and the reaction energy is −0.67 eV. For 2-butene, another HYD product, two possible routes exist (IM6 → IM8 → FS2 and IM5 → IM10 → FS3). In the former route, the C2–S scission first takes place via H migration from S1 to C2 (Reaction 8, IS8 → IM8; Fig. 8). This step is exothermic by 1.86 eV and the energy barrier is 0.68 eV. Finally, in Reaction 11, the adatom H transfers from Mo3 to C5, and 2-butene forms (IS11 → FS2; Fig. 8). This step is exothermic by 0.59 eV with an energy barrier of 0.84 eV. For the IM5 → IM10 → FS3 route, Reaction 10 (IS10 → IM10; Fig. S2) first takes place, in which the adatom H binds to C2. The oblique adsorbate molecule straightens after the hydrogenation reaction. This step is exothermic by 1.45 eV with an energy barrier of 0.93 eV. Notably, the intermediate in IM10 is identical to that in IM8; thus, the final hydrogenation reaction IM10 → FS3 (Reaction 12; Fig. S2) is the same as that in Reaction 11. In comparison, the elementary steps with 2-butene formations (Reactions 11 and 12) have slightly lower energy barriers than those with 1-butene formations (Reactions 13 and 14). For the thiophene HYD reactions to produce butane, our results show that its dentate intermediates result in the deviation of the adjacent S atoms on Mo-edge from their original positions, which causes negative effects on catalyst stability and H co-adsorption. That is, the increased steric hindrance prevents butane formation. For both DDS and HYD pathways at the edge CUS on MoS2 cluster, the following conclusions are reached. The DDS route is IS → IM1 → FS1 with the product of butadiene. By contrast, the desulfurization products along the HYD routes are 1-butane (IS → IM2 → IM5 → IM7 → FS5 and IS → IM2 → IM6 → IM9 → FS4) and 2-butene (IS → IM2 → M6 → IM8 → FS2 and IS → IM2 → IM5 → IM10 → FS3). Among all the HDS routes, the second thiophene CS bond scissions are regarded as the rate-determining steps because they possess the highest energy barriers in their respective HDS reaction routes. Compared with the HYD reactions, the DDS pathway is more favorable at the edge CUS due to the lower energy barrier in the rate-determining step and the shorter reaction process. 4 Conclusions In this work, DFT calculations were performed to investigate the competition in CUS formations and the HDS reaction mechanisms at diverse CUSs on MoS2 cluster. (1) Five active sites on 50% S-coverage Mo-edge were constructed and optimized. Single CUSs are more energetically favorable than the others because the existing vacancies restrain desorption of adjacent S atoms. Among the single CUSs, the corner CUS is more competitive than the edge CUS. The free energy variations indicate that higher H2 partial pressure and temperature are beneficial for CUS formation. (2) “Flat” adsorption through η5-type bonding is preferred by thiophene at the corner CUS, whereas the “vertical” adsorption is competitive at the edge CUS. The large adsorption energy, frontier molecular orbital and electrostatic potential analyses confirm that the corner CUS is the more favorable site for thiophene adsorption than the edge CUS. (3) At the corner CUS, the HYD route is more competitive than the DDS route during the hydrogenation reaction of thiophene. In the HYD reaction, the desulfurization product is 2-butene, but the sulfur-containing impurity tetrahydrothiophene would be simultaneously generated. (4) At the edge CUS, both HYD and DDS routes are possible. 1-butane and 2-butene are the possible desulfurization products during the HYD reactions, whereas the product of DDS reaction is butadiene. Given that the rate-determining step in the DDS route has the lowest energy barrier, this route is the most competitive among all the pathways at the corner and edge CUSs, and butadiene is the most favorable HDS products. coredata.dc:description: MoS2 is an efficient catalyst widely used in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) reaction. Coordinatively unsaturated active sites (CUS) on defective MoS2 clusters are the most active positions for HDS reaction. In this study, we investigated CUS formation competition and thiophene HDS reaction mechanism at diverse active sites on MoS2 nanoclusters by using density functional theory. First, we constructed five defective MoS2 clusters with different CUSs. The calculated formation energies and Gibbs free energies of these CUSs indicated that the MoS2 clusters with single-corner or -edge CUSs were the favorable structures under HDS condition, especially the former type. Subsequently, thiophene adsorption configurations and HDS reactions at the corner and edge CUSs on MoS2 clusters were elucidated. Results showed that the corner CUS was more beneficial for thiophene adsorption than the edge CUS due to the smaller steric hindrance effect. For HDS process at the corner CUS, reaction via hydrogenation route was more competitive, and the reaction formed 2-butene as a product and tetrahydrothiophene as an impurity. By contrast, at the edge CUS, the direct desulfurization route with butadiene production was more energetically favorable, indicating an enhanced catalytic HDS property. This work provides theoretical basis in screening catalyst active sites and catalytic reaction products in industrial HDS processes.
coredata.dc:title: Impact of diverse active sites on MoS2 catalyst: Competition on active site formation and selectivity of thiophene hydrodesulfurization reaction
